comments.message:
Test evidence covers Release17BP6 to Release17BP7. Any reason why Release17BP6 to Release17BP8 isn't covered?

Also any coverage for delta update? If not, it must be covered either by developer or validation team.

Hi Nasif, 
    Sorry the evidence of LE-16225 is "Evidence_fwupdate_Release17_BP8_TAOP package.txt" and "Evidence_FOTA_by_WP76xx_Release17_BP8_GENERIC.spk.txt" not Evidence_FOTA_R17BP6_to_R17BP7.txt (LE-16009 and [73491 #1)

    And delta part is also approved see "Evidence_fwupdate_delta_r17bp7_to_r17bp8.log"
Why change in dualsys? Didn't we sell the AR/Automative branch?

Rollback without modifying pa_fwupdate_dualsys.c 

Thanks for reviewing

Remove LE_NOT_POSSIBLE from APIs, and replace by an error code more suitable.

Resolves: LE-8997
Change-Id: Idecceb09a7d3d4c80c86047cf545db0ff6607f09
commits.subject: Remove LE_NOT_POSSIBLE from Legato

comments.message: Nasif, do you think this conversion good?
No, i don't think so. It should be something better
To make it easier for Thanh, Nasif, please suggest. Thanks.

Thanks Nasif, Andrew for review.
I was thinking of other enum but couldn't see which one is better.
If you think another enum is better, could you suggest it to me?
Thanks!
Probably better option to use LE_NOT_PERMITTED. As partitions aren't synchronized, no new firmware download isn't permitted
Thanks Nasif for your suggestion. Done

commits.commitMessage:
[FWUPDATE] Fix repeatly reboot when swap to a bad image

After fwupdate install and reboot, the swap reason of badimage
and unexpected reboot is not checked. This leads to repeatly
reboot.

Resolves: LE-13289
Related: LEAR7M-704
Change-Id: I948f2619b282b11d2f26e684577edc5bd71dfe72
Signed-off-by: Patrick Lai <plai@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [FWUPDATE] Fix repeatly reboot when swap to a bad image

comments.message: need a comment explaining why value(s) chosen. I.e. that SWAP_BY_LEGATO value has to match the SWAP_TRIGGERED_BY_LEGATO defined in such and such place.

commits.commitMessage:
Replace sleep() with le_thread_Sleep()

Replaced sleep() calls with a new le_thread_Sleep() function that will use
nanosleep() instead of sleep() as sleep() is implemented with the SIGALRM signal
which may introduce some bugs.

Resolves: LE-8202
Change-Id: I5814aded93cd0f66c1f06aaaff4ce1c431c8974c
commits.subject: Replace sleep() with le_thread_Sleep()

Fix coverity defects for fwupdate

* fwupdateDualsysUnitTest/fwupdateInitComponent/main.c and
fwupdateSinglesysUnitTest/fwupdateSinglesysInitComponent/main.c:
replace fscanf with fgets to make sure no overloaded string.

commits.commitMessage:
Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

strerror() and strerror_r() have different behaviour and different
prototypes depending on the system.  So replace these with a new
function LE_ERRNO_TXT() which will behave like strerror() but is
thread safe.

Resolves: LE-14026
Change-Id: Ic993b3e83dd6534422046ce883ecadf55c1d8404
commits.subject: Replace strerror() and strerror_r() with LE_ERRNO_TXT()

commits.commitMessage:
Fix fwupdate state machine

Fwupdate Daemon is changing state to STATUS_OK after successful
download, however, this STATUS_OK should only used when installation
successful. If sudden power-cut happens before after download but
before installation, avcDaemon got confused with this wrong state. Also
the writing the metadata to SWIFOTA partition should be done before
changing state to INSTALL_ONGOING.

Resolves: LE-13576
Change-Id: Ie9f30d5aca97a565f64fe27a27ede9ce9beacb08
commits.subject: Fix fwupdate state machine

comments.message: Is crash the best way to deal with string buffer overflow here? As I understand it's the only ASSERT in this file. Alternative could be print error; fclose; return LE_FAULT - that would be consistent with handling other errors in this function.
+1 to stan. This shouldn't be the ASSERT, better return LE_FAULT with and error log
Error message not descriptive enough. It should print what inside each buffer, what is the real size and what is expected etc.

+1 stan.

Better to use PRIuS. After ulegato merge, we are using PRIuS in stead of zu
Would work for sure. But I heard the plan is to eventually replace %zu/%zd by PRIuS/PRIdS everywhere, to make the code compatible with some weird compilers (that originated from uLegato).
Sounds good, thanks for the explanation, I'll update.

LE_ERROR("Buffer for vol0Name too small: vol0Name[%s][%"PRIuS"] ubiVolId[%d]",...

commits.commitMessage:
Fix delta update when target image has more ubi volume

Two more ubi volume (i.e. legato_hs and legato_rhs) were added as part
as part of dm-verity implementation. Current delta update can't handle
addition of these new ubi volumes. This patch added support to handle
addition of two dm-verity volume.

Resolves: LE-13283
Change-Id: I8c41774f724deb6688a66c87b7320a05cb8769a7
commits.subject: Fix delta update when target image has more ubi volume

comments.message: looks like it's not used anywhere?
Would it make sense to check metaHdrPtr->ubiVolId (against 1 and 2) before this call?

I don't think so. The idea here:
1. Get the volume info ubi file descriptor
2. If fails step 1 then generate ubi volume info for only for volume 1 or 2 as they are dm-verity hash volume (so their attributes are known/can-be-derived). For other volume (e.g. volume 0), throw an error.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix resume data corruption on sudden power-cut

FwupdateDaemon stores metadata of download as well as cached data for
flash eraseblock for supporting FOTA suspend/resume. Flash writing is
done block by block basis, hence downloaded data caching is required.
There is a chance of partial write if sudden power-cut happens during
data-transfer to physical device. This patch cross-check CRC32 of both
metadata as well as cached data to avoid any incoherency on
suspend/resume data.

Resolves: LE-13285
Change-Id: I4a41a39d670a27c5f990af70443b677599bc59ca
commits.subject: Fix resume data corruption on sudden power-cut

comments.message: I think PRIuS should be used for printing size_t.
This one was wrong. Changed to zd
All I'm saying, PRIuS is the preferable way to print size_t (instead of "%zu"), and PRIdS for ssize_t.
I don't like to use platform dependent stuffs (i.e. PRIuS/PRIdS) for size_t type (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/940087/whats-the-correct-way-to-use-printf-to-print-a-size-t)
The goal is the code portability to the compilers that don't support %z. If you think that PRIuS/PRIdS need to be deprecated in favour of %zu/%zd, this should be discussed by wider circle.

I am not telling to deprecate PRIuS/PRIdS. But I am against of using PRIuS/PRIdS for size_t/ssize_t because it's size is machine dependent. However, PRIuS/PRIdS can be used for types like uint32_t/uint64_t etc as size is known and it won't vary based on machine type.

PRIuS is intended to be used exclusively for size_t (and PRIdS for ssize_t).
For uint32_t/uint64_t, there are another macros PRIu32/PRIu64.

Sorry, I misunderstood. But still I don't find any strong logic for using PRIuS/PRIdS for size_t/ssize_t (Another online post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2125845/platform-independent-size-t-format-specifiers-in-c/22114959). This %z is specified in C99, are we going to use any compiler earlier than that? Am I missing anything?
we are using variable-size array declarations? Didn't know.

commits.commitMessage:
[FWUPDATE] Scan the flash before writing sbl image

Bad block is not handle in partition_WriteDataSBL(). When writing
sbl image into the partition, the flash is not scanned.
partition_CheckData() is called after writing the image and
will scan the flash. This leads to the leb and peb difference.

Resolves: LE-12481
Related: LEAR7M-611
Change-Id: I839612d57e2e2620cb958dc1e8a0cf02fd209a03
Signed-off-by: Patrick Lai <plai@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [FWUPDATE] Scan the flash before writing sbl image

commits.commitMessage:
Include ssl, zlib, bz2 libraries in fwupdateDaemon

Legato fwupdateDaemon was taking its ssl, zlib, bz2 libraries runtime
from rootfs, however, it may cause crashing of fwupdateDaemon if old
legato runs on upgraded rootfs. This patch modified fwupdateDaemon
build script to include these libraries during build time.

Resolves: LE-12635
Change-Id: Ieebe85cd0bac38b8dced2cbd9af73b5ed2f53952
commits.subject: Include ssl, zlib, bz2 libraries in fwupdateDaemon

comments.message: This is already in the fwupdate PA

commits.commitMessage:
[PA_FLASH] Enhance the PA flash unitary tests

Resolves: LE-11787
Change-Id: Ia7efbbbe96a58742add6ca5c6004cbfa8582de2a
commits.subject: [PA_FLASH] Enhance the PA flash unitary tests

comments.message: I think the commit msg should be updated because fixes has been made in pa level + unitary test updated

No. The PA changes/fixes are pointed by their own tickets. I just keep all the changes here to have the UT passed and the PA changes must disappear when we will have merged the dedicated tickets LE-11041, LE-12031 and LE-12041.
This is bitmask. A (b << n) will set bad block to b (1=bad,0=good) for the block n.
And what about adding a comment to explain this ? :)
Where do you test the result of the download ?
No need. This is done by the CRC. Remember that pa_fwupdate_Download() read the CRC from the .CWE and check that the CRC is the same in the flash.
certainly the same logic, but it could be nice to have details
is this related to the unit test update?
a lot of changes in this file, I'm not sure they are related to the unit test
should be LE_TEST_INFO (check all the file)
should be LE_TEST_ASSERT no? (same for other)
You should use LE_TEST_PLAN or LE_TEST_NO_PLAN somewhere
should be LE_TEST_INFO (check in all the file)
you should use LE_TEST_PLAN or LE_TEST_NO_PLAN somewhere
same comment than in other files about LE_TEST use
same comments than in other files about LE_TEST use

set errno
if you use the errno set by readlink perhaps adding a comment
Same in other following functions

break to be coherent with the previous break in the if ?
set errno
Are these values given in parameter when the test is run ? If yes, this description should go in the top of the file, to explain how using the test, with some examples
No. There is only one private case, when the env variable BAD_BLOCK_LEFWKRO2 is provided. I used it for debugging avoiding this way to recompile the UT.

commits.commitMessage:
[FWUPDATE] AVMS reports WDSI 15 after FOTA

When performing FOTA upgrade from the version before fwupdate PA
refactoring, to the version after refactoring, FOTA job returns
the failed result (although the firmware is actually upgraded).
The reason for failure is that new PA can't find the download
status file on the file system.
The fix is: if the download status file is not found, query the
modem the same way the system behaved before refactoring.

Resolves: LE-12382
Change-Id: Id19929a6cfa9b55bb679ee9c27bc5aeb8d061b0b
commits.subject: [FWUPDATE] AVMS reports WDSI 15 after FOTA

commits.commitMessage:
[PA_FLASH_UBI] PA flash UBI may destroy valid volume blocks

In case of bad blocks, pa_flash_Erase() will mark the block bad and
choose the next one. This is coherent when a flash partition contains
only images, but not when its supports a file system like ubi-fs or
squashfs or is an ubi container. In that case, the next block to use
must be chosen by the UBI layer.

Resolves: LE-12031
Change-Id: Ied9bdcb39423fe418970c596048977c457ecf7c9
commits.subject: [PA_FLASH_UBI] PA flash UBI may destroy valid volume blocks

comments.message: Yes, but I do not want to document this as the pa_flash_Erase() is a visible API and this error is only internal from UBI layer request.
ieb is a Logical block, ubiLebtoPeb returns a Pyhical block? Comparison is not homogeneous I think.

Agree. The name ubiLebToPeb is clearly wrong. This is an array from UBI LEB to MTD LEB (the other array lebToPeb is from MTD LEB to MTD PEB).
I propose to rename this field ubiLebToMtdLeb to prevent any confusion.
And if we find a block with erase count 0, we could just break the loop and use it as new block.
can we rebuild the ubi leb mapping in this function?
This is done by this pointer. We call EraseUbiBlock() with the leb to erase in IN/OUT (lebPtr). If leb change, this will be handled by the calling function. See example at lines 490-505.

I think the leb changing should be handle by this function so the caller won't need to worry about it, and the erase flow is more complete: leb mapping is not broken after the function return. Otherwise the caller need to check the leb changing every time it calls the function.
I will have a look how to proceed so.

[PA_FLASH] Service pa_flash_Write() never ends if write() returns -EIO

In the loop to restart writing after a block is erased due to a
-EIO error reported by write(2), the tryWrite boolean is reset to
false when the first page written succeeds.

Resolves: LE-12041
Change-Id: Id17bc42dd0a1dc24a9e564b3e6b5c85a9cf7e6a5

commits.commitMessage:
[DOTA] Set supplied UBI image sequence number

Add new API pa_flash_SetUbiImageSeqNum() to set the UBI image
sequence number supplied by meta data.
Internal interface partition_OpenUbiSwifotaPartition() updated to
handle this UBI image sequence number.
Single system fwupdate mechanism updated to create ubi partition
using this image sequence number

Resolves: LE-11336
Change-Id: Ic218476dc798b5f03251372b5d84183f7c2664eb
commits.subject: [DOTA] Set supplied UBI image sequence number

comments.message:
I think theoretically ubi sequence number zero is possible. So if ubi sequence number is zero then this will lead to a bug. So either one of the following things can be done:

1. Remove the UBI_IMAGE_SEQ_BASE completely. In that delta generated by old mkdelta won't work, just new mkdelta will be required. I think this is fine.

OR

2. Consider -1 to take default sequence number, and other positive number as regular sequence number. In that case, desPtr->ubiImageSeq may need to chage int64_t
This could be also renamed patchInfo.

I noticed this but I didn't changed it because in current implementation this segmentSize is really meaning segment-size, not something generic like patchInfo (which bears different info based on diff type)
Greater than 100 characters. Please, split this line.
Why did you move this block ?

Good question. Before ubi partition was created immediately after reading cwe header but this is not possible now because ubi sequence number isn't available when cwe header is read. It is only available when first patchMeta data is read. Hence I moved it to here.

I will put some comment to make this clear
But the volume ID 0 could be not the first and also, we can imagine an UBI w/o volume ID 0 but with another number. We must use a boolean here instead of checking for a volume ID.

Indeed good observation. 

As far as I understood, this was the simple and clean approach that's why I did it. I wasn't much interested to add another global boolean variable to keep track of whether a partition is created or not, store and restore for suspend/resume etc.

I consulted linux people in richmond  before implementing this and I was informed that there is no chance that we will release package that starts with non-zero ubi volume number and if someone created a ubi with non-zero ubi volume, kernel driver will most likely refuse it 
( From UBI website: Each record describes one UBI volume and record index in the volume table array corresponds to the volume ID. I.e, UBI volume 0 is described by record 0 in the volume table, and so on. Count of records in the volume table is limited by the LEB size, but cannot be greater than 128. This means that UBI devices cannot have more than 128 volumes. Reference: http://www.linux-mtd.infradead.org/doc/ubi.html#L_vol_table), .

commits.commitMessage:
[fwupdate] Sometimes markgood is failed

Add a parameter onlyChkValidUbiData to function of
partition_CheckData().
If it is an UBI empty block, we calculate CRC32 with
the first page data only. Else if it is an UBI block,
we calculate CRC32 with the data from the first page
to the last page that is not full of 0xff. Else we
calculate CRC32 with all the block data.

Resolves: LE-11156
Related: LEAR7M-401
Change-Id: I9a3c629778b3dd905accdb1672444fa407eac35c
Signed-off-by: Anson Ouyang <aouyang@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: [fwupdate] Sometimes markgood is failed

commits.commitMessage:
Introduce KConfig for Legato build configuration

The KConfig settings subsume a number of disparate settings that were
previously controlled by various environment variables and preprocessor
defines.  The legacy environment variables are still used to populate
the initial values if no configuration is present, however the KConfig
output has become the single point of truth for these values going
forward.

The default behaviour of "make" and "make <target>" is preserved.  In
addition, "make menuconfig" and "make menuconfig_<target>" can be used
to explicitly change the configuration values.

The largest changes are the addition of the new KConfig files defining
the options, and extensive modifications to the Makefiles to generate
and use the configured values.  Most of the rest of the changes are
modifying preprocessor directives and values to use the new
configuration names.

Resolves: LE-10145 LE-10147
Change-Id: I5a26ed9913f9bf722869b2dac720498bcedaf991
commits.subject: Introduce KConfig for Legato build configuration

commits.commitMessage:
[DOTA] Support of Suspend Resume

Resolves: LE-11137
Change-Id: I808dd1c88ce263a2df776465f1e6bc2f0421b2fe
commits.subject: [DOTA] Support of Suspend Resume

comments.message:
Add static before.
Static variables must start by an uppercase.
part[500000] is not acceptable (512K flash won't work).
The size must be adapted from the real erase block size, or the memory must be created at the first call to partition_GetPartitionInternals().
Pleas comment these variables.
This need to be written to disk with the global context I think.
Perhaps, force ImgDiff to false, in this case.
Same. Perhaps, for BsdDiff to false in that case.

Too long.
Please, remove the "####...." banner.
The first would be better in COMPONENT_INIT I guess.

Question: If we incur power trip after writing half of the ubi partition, should we need to start it again from the beginning? or UBI resume can be continued from the last block it was written successfully?
UBI will resume at the last couple (patch header/ patch data) and not in the beginning of the UBI partition.
Do we really need so many parameters?

I prefer not changing this function since it's not part of the current patch. 
For optimization changes, I suggest opening a dedicated ticket in order to simplify what can be simplified.
No needed. Should be inferred from curIndex and applyPatchState

Do we really need all these variables? Please note, FOTA upgrade for single system is different from FOTA upgrade in dual system. I think they are adapted from dual system code. In single system, FOTA upgrade is done by SBL (hence SBL already checks CRC32, length, product type etc etc) and as far as I know WP team have no plan to change this is near future. We probably can remove some of these checks and simplify the code.

Also inside this file, deltaUpdate and regular FOTA update is
tightly coupled, hence high chance that any bug in delta 
update (specially in suspend/resume) will be propagated to 
regular fota upgrade and vice versa. I think it's better to 
decouple them from each other. I know it's a good amount of 
effort but it is worth for long term maintainability of the 
code. Also suspend/resume is targeted for 18.11 release (so 
we have enough time to do this) 
   
Also I don't see any reason for parsing all individual CWE 
headers for regular fota upgrade. Parsing individual CWE 
probably needed for delta update. If full package has 
deltaUpdate, the top level SPKG header must have delta flag 
enabled.

1) Parsing each CWE header is a MUST in order to be be able to resume when inside an image block. We don't want to go back to the last CWE header and rewrite it again especially if we already written a good part of that image block.
So, we need to parse and store the last CWE header, we need to know the image type, size and CRC. These variables are needed, that's why they are part of the context and saved.

2) I disagree about removing the CRC32 calculations because in that case we'll be blind folded and only rely on the SBL final check.
On FOTA, there will be waste of bandwidth since we'll download a corrupt package, flash the partition and reboot the target in vain. With the CRC32 calculations, we have more chances to stop the download earlier.
In case of Delta, we won't be able to know if the computed chunk CRC is the same as in the CWE header

3) I don't have any opinion about whether we should decouple deltaUpdate and fwupdate_siglesys but as said previously, since it's an optimization, I can't do it in this ticket. I try to make small changes to make the suspend/resume working.

> 1) Parsing each CWE header is a MUST in order to be be able to
 > resume when inside an image block. We don't want to go back to the
 > last CWE header and rewrite it again especially if we already
 > written a good part of that image block.
 > So, we need to parse and store the last CWE header, we need to know
 > the image type, size and CRC. These variables are needed, that's
 > why they are part of the context and saved.

Theoretically parsing individual CWE header only necessary for *DeltaUpdate*, not regular *full* FOTA upgrade. Please note we were already doing full FOTA upgrade without parsing individual header in old pa_fwupdate_qmi.c. As *full* FOTA and *deltaUpdate* is tightly coupled, we are bringing unwanted complexity of parsing individual cwe headers in full FOTA upgrade. 

 > 
 > 2) I disagree about removing the CRC32 calculations because in that
 > case we'll be blind folded and only rely on the SBL final check.
 > On FOTA, there will be waste of bandwidth since we'll download a
 > corrupt package, flash the partition and reboot the target in vain.
 > With the CRC32 calculations, we have more chances to stop the
 > download earlier.
 > In case of Delta, we won't be able to know if the computed chunk
 > CRC is the same as in the CWE header
 


Here again comes the question of simplification and decoupling full FOTA and deltaUpdate. 

 - For full FOTA upgrade, customer probably won't purposefully put a package with bad crc32 (hence it is not a regular usecase), if someone put it, SBL will detect it upon reboot.
 - For deltaUpdate, it is probably better to do these crc32 calculation.

Also, I don't see any reason for keeping following 6 crc

    uint32_t imageCrc;              ///< Image CRC
    uint32_t currentImageCrc;       ///< Current image CRC
    uint32_t globalCrc;             ///< CRC of all the package (crc in first cwe header)
    uint32_t currentGlobalCrc;   
    uint32_t fullImageCrc;          ///< Current CRC of the full image
    uint32_t inImageCrc;  

When I was coding this file, all these 6 crc confused me a lot. If we want to keep crc calculation in here, theoretically, we only need 2 crc32 to store (only imageCrc and globalCrc need to store to check after image reconstruction, others seem useless. We can get rid of currentImageCrc by storing partitionOffset after writing cweHeaders and calling partition_ComputeDataCrc32SwifotaPartition when whole image is written)

 > 3) I don't have any opinion about whether we should decouple
 > deltaUpdate and fwupdate_siglesys but as said previously, since
 > it's an optimization, I can't do it in this ticket. I try to make
 > small changes to make the suspend/resume working.

There is 3 CRCs and not 6
- currentImageCRC is updated periodically and compared against imageCRC at the end
- same for currentGlobalCrc and globalCrc

-  fullImageCrc is used in partition.c to check if the write process is correct.

-inImageCrc: I'll remove this one
Remove them. This should be picked up from patchMetaHdr

Why do we need so many offset to keep track? Having many global variables open new holes for bugs.

Also what is the purpose of CurrentOutImageOffset in case of delta update context? For ubi container, it won't makes sense by just simply adding amount of data written in swifota partition (ubi headers and other ubi meta already does some shifting).

CurrentReadPackageOffset: This one is needed. It keeps track of where we are in the package at any moment. We can't remove it.

CurrentInImageOffset: Usefull to keep track of where we are in a given image component.

Agree about the CurrentOutImageOffset, it can be removed differently. It's only used to open SWIFOTA partition. when we didn't write anything yet. I'll try to remove it.
Remove this. Better manage this via deltaUpdatePatchMetaHdr. No need add any extra global variables We already has so many global variables and code become quite convoluted with many global variables
We probably can infer both resume and isCreate flag by looking at curIndex and applyPatchState. Should be similar for bsdiff case
I don't see how. can you give me more details?

The idea here:
When patchIndex > 0  and patchIndex < NumPatches--> resume = true
Otherwise, resume = false

The opposite trick can be used for isCreate flag (when last patch applied, isCreate will be true, otherwise it is false)

Why isCreate is required by api?

We can't merge the two. I need two variables. First one keeps track of if the volume is created. The second one, tells if we need to resume.
I've moved these in deltaUpdate as advised previously.
Any reason why it is not removed?
We probably can get rid of both of these crc and their calculation. An way is mentioned in other comment (by removal of currentImageCrc)

I'm sorry but it's not up to me to take the decision to remove or not CRCs and it's not the purpose of the ticket.

Why don't we suggest this idea in another ticket and discuss it with architects?

Why this state is set to 1 here? As I mentioned earlier, this type of code is violation of encapsulation design principle. Also setting state of imgpatch state-machine may in multiple files may introduces some bug. If we need to init the resume context, then we can create a new function applyPatch_InitResumeCtx() and update the context over there

This is violation of encapsulation design principle. applyPatchState is an enum and it's usage should be limited to imgpatch directory. Better to access it via some function applyPatch_IsFirstPatch() or applyPatch_IsBeginning() or something similar. 

Also why do we need this check? Here we are writing cwe header, yet not reach patch processing. So this one must be zero (or has to be init to zero by calling applyPatch_Init()). Anything I am missing?

commits.commitMessage:
[DOTA] partition_Open*Swifota() services must restart without erasing

For Suspend/Resume, partition.c must provide services to open the
SWIFOTA partition, open UBI and open UBI volume without erasing the
previous data flashed.
Moreover new services partition_GetPartitionInternals() and
partition_SetPartitionInternals() are also provided to save and
restore internals variables before calling some flash services in
the way to resume flash update from an interrupted point.

Resolves: LE-11207
Change-Id: I917e6a2fe32c388e78f9e59c42b882db7cfd1d14
commits.subject: [DOTA] partition_Open*Swifota() services must restart without erasing

comments.message: I think this variable is not really needed and can be removed from the file;

Sonar [MAJOR c:S2324]

> Remove this flexible array member.
Maybe add a log here to notify that the test won't be executed.
is this intended or only for debugging?

This is expected. This module supports all services that are expected to be switched to sys_flash*() [see https://gerrit-legato/#/c/Legato/platformAdaptor/fwupdate/+/35939/11/apps/test/fwupdateSuspendResumeUnitTest/Component.cdef]. This is to avoid any recursion. By the way, the write() here must really be write(2).
I will add a comment.

This is strange to me to have a function to get an internal context, which is not exposed in other functions.
What about this:
- the user layer is in charge of allocating a buffer of size Partition_t
- a pointer on this buffer is given in all APIs
-  there's no copy of this pointer in partition.c (no PartitionPtr)

Then the user layer can save the context when it wants (and so restore it).
Only a suggestion, what is done is fine.
Not used anymore, should we remove it?
No. Because forceCreate may be set to true above (line 1434).
No. Because createVol may be set to true in the block above (line 1686)

Klocwork [Critical NPD.CHECK.MIGHT #4097 @ wp76xx]

> Pointer 'lengthPtr' checked for NULL at line 1353 may be dereferenced at line 1361.

commits.commitMessage:
[DOTA] Implement target processing for delta patch

- Implemented delta patch target processing for full image reconstruction
  from delta image. Delta image may consists of ubi patches (modem,
  rootfs, legato) or raw bsdiff patches (kernel); fwupdateDaemon uses
  imgpatch for ubi patches and bspatch for raw bsdiff patches.

- Added unit test for both ubi and raw bsdiff patches.

Resolves: LE-9938
Related: LE-11047
Change-Id: I58afd7b29df8504b3ba9a8c9e7128e6406b1a8df
commits.subject: [DOTA] Implement target processing for delta patch

comments.message:
Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3902 @ wp76xx]

> 'volSize' might be used uninitialized in this function.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3903 @ wp76xx]

> 'crc' might be used uninitialized in this function.
Just a sample to share with Nasif.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3902 @ wp76xx]

> 'volSize' might be used uninitialized in this function.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3903 @ wp76xx]

> 'crc' might be used uninitialized in this function.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3902 @ wp76xx]

> 'volSize' might be used uninitialized in this function.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MIGHT #3903 @ wp76xx]

> 'crc' might be used uninitialized in this function.

I totally disagree about the usage of LE_ASSERT()/LE_FATAL() inside daemons. Crashing the daemon here, will also terminates all clients processes. What is the interest?
Also some resources (files,...) may remain after this.
Why do not return an error code instead?

We already have bsPatch() function inside the fwupdateDaemon.
Why do we use an executable here? This is the same code...

I need the plain bspatch() api which will be bspatch(src_file, out_file, patch_file). Idea of this ticket (https://issues.sierrawireless.com/browse/LXSWIREF-783) was to provide bsdiff/bspatch tool as well as some bspatch library. However, as it doesn't work, it put this an interim solution. imgpatch uses bspatch as intermediate tool, not always final output of bspatch is written to partition. Another way to put some imgpatch deflate code inside pa_patch which I don't like because it is a violation of software engineering practice (high cohesion, low coupling) and will add a future maintenance headache

And when the size is 0, what do pass as length argument to WriteData() ?
If WriteData() receives 0 as length, it will return 0 as so the services will fails.
I think that here we must keep the while() loop and have a non-null length to pass it the WriteData().
Could be removed as discussed with Brad when modem UBI images will be built correctly.
Could be removed as discussed with Brad when modem UBI images will be correctly built.
This is a volume type (8bits) not a volume id (16bits).
I guess this will be 'false' when suspend resume will be implemented.
The value must depends of resume or not. I think a new argument for OpenUbiVolume() has to be added to deal with.
The function name is "CloseUbiVolume" but inside there is this CRC computation, I suggest maybe rename the function "CloseAndVerifyUbiVolue" ?
I think this is already done in ubierror.
Maybe a while loop will be better if write doesn't write the wrLen in one shot?

sizeof returns a size_t, so, I would put %zu and remove the cast to (uint32_t).
Same in line 124, 144, ..
align the comments in this file,

Just notifying that this file doesn't follow Legato coding rules
- Variable naming: "src_start" should be "srcStart"
- Enums/Struct should be in Uppercase:applyPatchMeta_t should be ApplyPatchMeta_t
- Braces {}: Braces should be opened after the if statement and not same line.
-...
Since this function is not static, maybe check pointers (like the function below)
Magic number? Maybe use BUFFER_SIZE instead
This is wrong. I saw failure in installation when legato is the last image

Klocwork [Critical NPD.FUNC.MIGHT #3995 @ wp76xx]

> Pointer 'inflatedTgtData' returned from call to function 'malloc' at line 395 may be NULL and may be dereferenced at line 405.

Klocwork [Critical NPD.CHECK.CALL.MUST #3996 @ wp76xx]

> Pointer 'lengthPtr' checked for NULL at line 593 will be passed to function and may be dereferenced there by passing argument 6 to function 'deltaUpdate_ApplyUbiImgPatch' at line 594.
Why is this removed ? This expected to be part of the test for coverage.
This file is reverted versus LE-11047 delivery.
This files is reverted versus LE-11047 delivery.
This file is reverted versus LE-11047 delivery.
Wondering why an uint32_t for an index? What's the max value for this index? 9?
I think this variable is not used and can be removed
Add in the comment or in the function name that it computes and write.
a memcpy(&(saveCtxPtr->metaImgData),chunkPtr, length) would have been enough, right?
When does this case happen?  If ParseCweHeader is only called after checking size and IMAGE_TYPE_META CWE have a different size than a regular CWE, this should not happen. right?
I don't like this because we are writing data when the function is supposed to Parse. It makes the function ParseAndStoreData() hard to maintain.
This function became hard to follow
Maybe return here if result != LE_OK, this way, we can remove the if in 1502.

commits.commitMessage:
[DOTA] Implement bsPatch for RAW delta update

RAW partitions (like kernel) are patched with bspatch when
updating by delta.
In case of DOTA images, the checksum and length of an image is
broken by the delta patch. This will require two new services
partition_OpenSwifotaPartition() and partition_CloseSwifotaPartition()
to prevent any close performed by the partition low layer according
to an unexpected size or rejected due to a bad checksum.
Add 'META' in CWE header type list.

Resolves: LE-11047
Change-Id: Ide55a5957828b9db346cef2636a1b574aff2381d
commits.subject: [DOTA] Implement bsPatch for RAW delta update

comments.message:
Klocwork [Critical RNPD.DEREF #3973 @ wp76xx]

> Suspicious dereference of pointer 'ctxPtr' before NULL check at line 346

Klocwork [Critical NPD.CHECK.MIGHT #3974 @ wp76xx]

> Pointer 'lengthPtr' checked for NULL at line 563 may be dereferenced at line 580.

Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "destMode".

Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "destMode".

Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "destMode".

Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "destMode".
Only one element in the union?
Yes. This union is expected to be enhanced if new patches formats are developped. Currently, only flash are supported.
Maybe check that the destination size is > the source size ?
Partition must representative of the real material. So the 2 first PEB must exist.
If I read 100 chars, and write only 40, and I re-read 100 chars in the next loop, doesn't this means that 60 chars are dropped? Need to lseek each iteration I think
This is wrong.Cwe For composite image i.e. yocto.cwe offset is always larger than imgSize

OK. BUt this patch only apply to bsdiff for RAW. This is the first step before LE-9938.
So, if it is wrong, what is the good way, as deltaUpdate.c and CWE parsing is not the same as LE-9938.
if LE_DEBUG2 == LE_DEBUG, why redefining the macro ?
This is to put it LE_INFO instead of LE_DEBUG to prevent from a big big amount of traces. Anyway, this LE_DEBUG2 messages are expected to be removed when code will be mature in 18.10.
Why ? I guess if a bad block is met, it is bypassed and we jump to the next block, right ?
If I read and the current block is reported bad (LE_IO_ERROR) I have no way to read the data... The block data is corrupted, so the operation aborts.

commits.commitMessage:
Fix system reboot error code check

The system call error code check is not done correctly. This results in
a timeout issue on the fwupdate host side since the fwupdateService is
unable to return a result code to the host.

Resolves: LE-11070
Change-Id: I56b26077841b321e26a10dfec6dca7a678a7d343
commits.subject: Fix system reboot error code check

comments.message:
I don't know if this is the right behaviour.

First, there's a syscall reboot, so we do not need to be calling the external binary.  (This can be a large overhead for little to to no gain.)

Second, it looks like the busybox just calls the syscall and returns it's error code directly.  Looking at the syscall manpage I see that yes, it returns 0 or -1 but, you should check ERRNO, (which you can not do here as ERRNO is set in the child process, not this one.)  ERRNO can be set to a few different values, including permission denied, so this code needs to deal with this appropriately, (otherwise it could potentially hang forever.)

This behaviour is better than the existing behaviour. The current fwupdate on wp76xx just hangs in the while loop indefinetly and never returns an error code. This results in a timeout error on the host side. 

It does not affect the fwupdate operation but just not desired if user wants to check the error code of fwupdate on the host side.
Just looking at this, I think we can still easily get infinite hangs.

The behaviour we end up seeing seems to depend on if 

  ENABLE_FEATURE_INITRD

is enabled or not.

These tests are first related to the UBI at offset feature for
DOTA on wp76xx/wp77xx.

Clean-up all entry path dependant from #ifdef LEGATO_EMBEDDED.

comments.message:
Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "ec".

Sonar [MAJOR c:S1854]

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "size".
Why not using LE_TEST_ like in the other files?
Because... I do not know that LE_TEST_ exist !

If I understand correctly, this is the emulation of the flash. It is used by many (all?) pa_fwupdate unit tests. Do you think this emulation could be moved outside a unit test, as a common and independent component (directly in apps/test) ?

commits.commitMessage:
[WP76XX/WP77XX] UBI partition at any absolute offset

Add an absolute offset for UBI partition and volumes. Normally,
UBI partition use the whole partition starting at offset 0. For
SWIFOTA, UBI and RAW are mixed and so UBI partitions may be
located everywhere.

Add pa_flash_ReadUbiAtOffset() function

- This function allows to read from an UBI volume starting at
  any given offset.
- There is no limitation on the length. The function will perform
  in a best effort way to return the maximum possible read data

Resolves: LE-10326 LE-10283
Change-Id: I914b96d6b9f05c84b1d758fb2ad4a6b1fd1795cf
commits.subject: [WP76XX/WP77XX] UBI partition at any absolute offset

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "res".

> Remove this useless assignment to local variable "res".

> Add curly braces around the nested statement(s) in this "if" block.

Klocwork [Critical UNINIT.STACK.MUST #3872 @ wp76xx]

> 'res' is used uninitialized in this function.

Sonar [MAJOR c:S121]

> Add curly braces around the nested statement(s) in this "if" block.

Sonar [MAJOR c:S121]

Sonar [MAJOR c:S121]

> Add curly braces around the nested statement(s) in this "for" block.
No LE_SHARED for this one. Is it expected?
I don't understand the name of the function. It is supposed to only check, I assumed it will return a boolean but it returns an offset. Moreover, it performs some updates inside the descPtr.
Agree. I will rename it UpdateUbiAbsOffset().
This only works if eraseSize is 2^n. Why not use offset % eraseSize which is always correct
eraseSize is always a 2^n. And this operation is faster than %.

In case of Absolute offset, the UBI block is crossing two PEBs. It is not possible to erase it, before reading the 2 PEB, replace the data into the 2 PEBs, erase the 2 PEBs and write them. These operations are performed by FlashWriteBlock()below.
LE_FORMAT_ERROR and LE_BAD_PARAMETER missing. Same in the functions above

Why it is said ?
I prefer to reference with structure than variable for sizeof().
Really need this dual system dependency ?
Why do we have this file ? Would be done into the Component.cdef, isn't it ?

Because if preset in pa_flash mk... will the pa_flash_local.h from this directory. But I want THIS from mdm07/le_pa_fwupdate_singlesys.
This is only a symbolic link.
But -1 is a possible value, and is <0 :)
Erase ops is performed by FlashWrite() in case of UBI at offset. In this case, the FlashEraseBlock() do nothing and return LE_OK.
are we sure that this is not < 0 ?
Yes. Check is done by UpdateUbiAbsOffset() above.
Yes. Check is done by UpdateUbiAbsOffset() above.

No. Traces flagged with LE_DEBUG3 are expected to be removed after this code has run and get maturity.
Else, it will be very too verbose.
ok for the last gerrit comment, but may be nice to add a comment in the code

commits.commitMessage:
[fwupdate] Check swap status after install

Issue:
If an unexpected reset occurs during a fwupdate install, the swap
to the new image is not performed.
However, the installation status is marked OK instead of error.

Fix:
This issue has been fixed by adding new internal states for
firmware install. These states are catched at startup.
If an ongoing swap has been interrupted, the install is restarted.

Resolves: LE-10560
Relates: LEAR7M-359
Change-Id: I9336df4a994b3ccffadda50b529c6286db0d6452
commits.subject: [fwupdate] Check swap status after install

Why Ptr. This is not a pointer to a bool (bool*) ?
What is the interest of this variable ?

commits.commitMessage:
Add pa_flash_ReadUbiAtOffset() function

- This function allows to read from an UBI volume starting at
   any given offset.

- There is no limitation on the length. The function will perform
  in a best effort way to return the maximum possible read data

Resolves: LE-10283
Change-Id: I2ad6731df05c06f851c38dc34b913f2f53568204
commits.subject: Add pa_flash_ReadUbiAtOffset() function

  using pa_flash APIs

commits.commitMessage:
[PA FLASH] Function pa_flash_Erase() mismatches between PEB and LEB

The service pa_flash_Erase() will mark a block BAD if the erase
sequence fails. If the PA flash works with LEB, it will call
pa_flash_MarkBadBlock() with PEB instead of the LEB. The block
marked BAD won't be the expected one, pa_flash_MarkBadBlock()
will assume the PEB as a LEB.

Resolves: LE-10584
Change-Id: I2b91f181853a7d6f84a175dcbcc64d65f0863d89
commits.subject: [PA FLASH] Function pa_flash_Erase() mismatches between PEB and LEB

commits.commitMessage:
Support dataSize not multiple of writeSize in pa_flash_Write()

Linux NAND driver requires that all write(2) calls have a size
of a multiple of the write size (/sys/class/mtd/mtd*/writesize).
If not, the PA flash will pad the remaining bytes to FF and
always call write(2) on a write size buffer.

Resolves: LE-9991
Change-Id: I0fa845eaab3d13dea5e92560a54a4017f1a04f40
commits.subject: Support dataSize not multiple of writeSize in pa_flash_Write()

comments.message:
Except if rule change, the 1st line should not exceed 50 chars

commits.commitMessage:
Reduce fwupdateDaemon CPU load while computing partition CRC

Prevent hardware watchdog and lack of CPU resources by suspending
the fwupdateDaemon on each block before computing the partition
CRC.

Resolves: LE-9427
Change-Id: I3d537a196bd7de4d2330ef90a66ef3bac2438b9d
commits.subject: Reduce fwupdateDaemon CPU load while computing partition CRC

commits.commitMessage:
Fix incorrect usage of ioctl() ECCGETSTATS

ECCGETSTATS is used to record the the numbers of unhandled ECC errors
and corrected ECC errors from power on. after partition is erased,
the actual ECC erros number should be 0, can't use ECCGETSTATS to
decide the current ECC status in the partition

Resolves: LE-8741
Related: LEAR7M-131
Change-Id: I0f5a49e228cacc6e02cffea8c7274c4c4544de3c
commits.subject: Fix incorrect usage of ioctl() ECCGETSTATS

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think something is wrong here: as we are using le_fs to have access to the file system, we should use /tmp automatically. Could you please check why it doesn't work please ?

Patch Set 1:

Hello Anthony,
In fs_Init() function, see below code:
#define FS_PREFIX_DATA_PATH      "/data/le_fs/"
    char* fsPrefixArray[] =
    {
        FS_PREFIX_DATA_PATH,    
        "/tmp" FS_PREFIX_DATA_PATH,
        NULL,
    };
This function will check the accessibility for "/data/le_fs/" path. If this path does not exists then it will access "/tmp/data/le_fs/" path.
In unit test case, "/data/le_fs" path does not exist. So it will access "/tmp/data/le_fs/" path.

Patch Set 1:

Hi Pinkesh,

Yes, exactly. So the flag LEGATO_EMBEDDED in pa_fwupdate_dualsys.c could be removed.

Patch Set 1:

Hello Anthony,

In pa_fwupdate_dualsys.c file - GetResumeCtx() function is calling le_fs_Open(filepath, LE_FS_RDONLY,...).
In this scenario, it will just open the file with the file name as "filepath" input argument given le_fs_Open.
It will not append /tmp/data/le_fs/ or /data/le_fs/.
So for unit test cases, the execution gets failed for le_fs_Open(filepath, LE_FS_RDONLY) scenario.

Please give your suggestion to solve this issue.

Patch Set 1:

"It will not append /tmp/data/le_fs/ or /data/le_fs/."
It was linked to my previous question: why le_fs_Open doesn't append /tmp ? Is this function a stub, or is it coming from the liblegato ?

Patch Set 1:

It is the problem from the liblegato.
in fs.c file, le_fs_Open() there is an issue.

ok, thanks. Please submit a ticket for this.

comments.message: Shouldn't you use a Legato interface instead of this function?

This is not possible to have an error with the NULL parameter. See man 2 time.
Even in case of error here, this must not stop the current update operation.

This is not possible to have an error with the NULL parameter. See man 2 time.

RETURN VALUE
       On  success,  the value of time in seconds since the Epoch is returned.
       On error, ((time_t) -1) is returned, and errno is set appropriately.

ERRORS
       EFAULT t points outside your accessible address space.


Even in case of error, this must not stop the current update operation.
Shouldn't you use a Legato interface instead of this function?
Do you have an idea about the load increased for a download. Reading time at each chunk may increase the duration...
Outside of certain targets (some AWS machines, for example), getting time is relatively quick in my experience.

commits.commitMessage:
Do not copy 0xFF to the end of the block to UBI partition

Description:
During fwupdate markGood, It will copy all the data from
AC partition to UD partition including 0xFF. So all the
blocks have been fully wrote in UD partition, but UBI will
treats the rest of NAND pages which has only 0xFF data as
empty pages, and will write data on it without erase first.
It will bring ECC error (at next time read), if NAND pages
being wrote without erase first.

Root cause:
During fwupdate, It copy the data 0xFF that locate at the rest
of NAND pages to the block in UD system for UBI partition.

Solution:
Remove the 0xFF data (align with page size) which is located
at the rest of the blocks for UBI.

Resolves: LE-8911
Cherry-pick: LEAR7M-171 LEAR7M-164
Change-Id: I985f1be452202663b7724a6839b04db74f4c693e
Signed-off-by: Caupar Gu <CGu@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Do not copy 0xFF to the end of the block to UBI partition

comments.message:
Not sure about this condition: we should find the free block which has the minimum ec, whatever the mean, right ?
This test forbid to use a block which has been often use. But if we have no choice, we have to use it...
This is what it is done.

this is not a correct way to compute a mean value:
mean1 =(A+B)/2
mean2 = (A+B+C)/3
but (mean1+C)/2 != mean2
I don't know, but perhaps this is sufficient for the usage.
ubiMinEraseCount and ubiMaxEraseCount could be removed as there are not used anymore

But they are now part of the structure mtdInfo exported to customer.
It may be also interesting for statistics usage of a partition...
But, I agree that we can remove them. Also the same with the field ubiWlThreshold...
I think in that case, we should let it to the max value UBI_MAX_ERASECOUNTER. Otherwise, we could use this block instead of another with a smaller ec

commits.commitMessage:
Allow fwupdate to update the image of partition customer2

Description:
When there is a customer2 image in package xx.cwe/xx.spk, then
use the command "fwupdate download xx.cwe/xx.spk" to update
the image for customer2 will get fail return.

Root cause:
Partition customer2 is not in BadImageMask list. So can't get
any bad image info for it, update stop.

Solution:
Add partition customer2 to the BadImageMask list.

Resolves: LE-8742
Cherry-pick: LEAR7M-132
Change-Id: I33e3951d28f4681a0516efb58ee532a912c4877f
Signed-off-by: Caupar Gu <CGu@sierrawireless.com>
commits.subject: Allow fwupdate to update the image of partition customer2

Patch Set 1:

Looking closely at the dualsys code, seems hanging epoll_wait won't show up here although edge triggered event is used here. Here, read() is done inside while loop and epoll_wait() is only called when read returns EAGAIN which is different from wp76/wp85 code. In wp76/wp85 code, epoll_wait is called before almost every read(). Discarding this patch

Abandoned

No need. Existing should already handle this issue

commits.commitMessage:
Change epoll flag from edge trigger to level trigger

If epoll_ctl is configured with EPOLLET (edge triggered), there is
a chance where epoll_wait() may hang indefinitely. For details,
please see:http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/epoll.7.html. Due to
this issue sometimes LE_AVC_DOWNLOAD_COMPLETE may not be received at
all although avcDaemon passed the package completely to fwupdateDaemon
This issue is fixed here.

Resolves: LE-7536
Change-Id: I815cca511780a4aa88f6f24db9380c4ddab8f5a4
commits.subject: Change epoll flag from edge trigger to level trigger

comments.message:
I'm not agree because if you read all the man page you can see:
"An application that employs the EPOLLET flag should use nonblocking file descriptors to avoid having a blocking read or write starve a task that is handling multiple file descriptors.  The suggested way to use epoll as an edge-triggered (EPOLLET) interface is as follows:

   i   with nonblocking file descriptors; and
   ii  by waiting for an event only after read(2) or write(2) return EAGAIN."

And we're using a non-blocking fd and we're waiting the event only after read (see PrepareFd() and ReadSync() ) ...

This is the way blocking read/write can be avoided but it can't avoid sticking on epoll_wait()(which is called in ReadSync function) which was mentioned previously on the man page

"      The epoll event distribution interface is able to behave both as
       edge-triggered (ET) and as level-triggered (LT).  The difference
       between the two mechanisms can be described as follows.  Suppose that
       this scenario happens:

       1. The file descriptor that represents the read side of a pipe (rfd)
          is registered on the epoll instance.

       2. A pipe writer writes 2 kB of data on the write side of the pipe.

       3. A call to epoll_wait(2) is done that will return rfd as a ready
          file descriptor.

       4. The pipe reader reads 1 kB of data from rfd.

       5. A call to epoll_wait(2) is done.

       If the rfd file descriptor has been added to the epoll interface
       using the EPOLLET (edge-triggered) flag, the call to epoll_wait(2)
       done in step 5 will probably hang despite the available data still
       present in the file input buffer; meanwhile the remote peer might be
       expecting a response based on the data it already sent. "

I am noticing the same issue when I instrument the fwupdateDaemon code.  Specially when last few KB data is passed via write end of the pipe and read end do a partial read which causes edge triggered event to be vanished although there is data is pipe. So subsequent epoll_wait hang for ever and never receive DOWNLOAD_COMPLETE.
The problem is that the EPOLLET has been added to avoid some freeze ...
What are those freeze? Can you please provide some details?

I tend to agree with Nasif here. The risk is that EPOLLET stops signalling the reader if received data was partially read, but more data is still available. In this case the reader may hang on a partially-read last packet of data. This would never happen if EPOLLIN was used because it would keep signalling until all data is read out.

Was there an explicit intention to use EPOLLET? If yes, then we should have it described in order to justify it.
Assignee changed from: Gaetan Perrier <gpe@sierrawireless.com> to: Jean Thomas <jeanthomas@sierrawireless.com>
Assignee changed from: Jean Thomas <jeanthomas@sierrawireless.com> to: Anthony Doussain <ado@sierrawireless.com>
Assignee changed from: Anthony Doussain <ado@sierrawireless.com> to: Gilles Raynal <graynal@sierrawireless.com>

commits.commitMessage:
[SW Update] Manage ECC errors to prevent bad synchronization

Check for unrecoverable ECC errors during the synchronization and
abort if active or dual returns some ECC errors.
If an ECC error is found while le_fwupdate_InitDownload(), the
mode UPDATE without SYNC is enabled to allow a whole update of
the dual.
Recompute the source checksum for UBI partition. Redo a try if
the checksum does not match to prevent against UBI access by
UBI driver while synchronizing.

Resolves: LE-7699
Change-Id: I72b12d3de8c69f3795999858f9437c84ea187cb3
commits.subject: [SW Update] Manage ECC errors to prevent bad synchronization

commits.commitMessage:
Replace deprecated readdir_r with readdir.

Evidently, POSIX screwed up when they introduced readdir_r;
in fact readdir doesn't have inherent re-entrancy issues because
it has the "DIR *" context object which can hold the dirent
structure that is returned by each call to readdir. Each
thread has its own DIR, and everything is cool.

Glibc now marks the readdir_r function as deprecated and the
toolchain warns when it is used, breaking -Werror builds.

* mdm9x40/le_pa_fwupdate_dualsys/partition.c (partition_CheckIfMounted):
Rework readdir_r code with readdir.

Resolves: LXSWIREF-91
Change-Id: If2750531b7b98ab733483c29e45683408c01c59c
commits.subject: Replace deprecated readdir_r with readdir.

comments.message:
Maybe while you're at it add a check against errno here so you can differentiate end-of-directory from an error?  The readdir(3) man page says you need to set errno = 0 before the call, then check errno after.

No a big issue though as the old code had the same problem.
The scope of the related ticket (yocto 2.2 build) is already quite big so I'm not sure Kaz will have time to address this. Might be best to have it as a separate issue/fix.

commits.commitMessage:
[SW update] Interaction between UBI devices and fwupdateDaemon

This concerns two operations:
 - Wear-Leveling,
 - Scrubbing.

Two cases:
 - If wear-leveling threshold is over EC (max - min), the UBI layer
   may have start the wear-leveling mechanism on this partition,
 - If the EC max or EC min have changed during the copy, the UBI layer
   may have performed a scrubbing on this partition.

If a case above is true, we recompute the checksum to ensure that the
source was not modified by the UBI layer during the copy.

Resolves: LE-7190
Change-Id: Ie40039b57635deede336b07b2095ae67e8b1e5f5
commits.subject: [SW update] Interaction between UBI devices and fwupdateDaemon

comments.message: Perhaps, this could be called before performing the copy
With Ptr and remove following blank line.
Not answer to the coding rules
I think this function is useless, all required information  would be into flashInfoDstPtr
I think we should do this when a partition is opened in read mode on its closure operation. What do you think ?
not sure this is correctly computed... can you check please?
we could use pa_flash_Info_t instead. The function may be called pa_flash_UpdateUbiInfo

please explain what you are doing here.
Do we need to call pa_flash_CheckUbiIntegrity() just after opening the partition ?

Because to check integrity of UBI, we need to perform a comparison between old EC and current EC. To keep, the value, we need to open the flash device, perform a check integrity (function returns LE_FORMAT_ERROR if it does not stand an UBI container).
same comment as the previous file, do we need this call here ?
how do we know we are working on a UBI partition here ?

I will put a better documentation for this function.
This function use return codes as follow:
- LE_OK : This an UBI and its integrity is OK or this is the first call.
- LE_FORMAT_ERROR : This is not an UBI, so this service cannot work on it.
-LE_WOULD_BLOCK : The UBI seems to be corrupted due to an external write access (The error code is not the better, but...). It means, that normally someone should be blocked during the other access to the flash...
- others : Flash operation error/parameter error.

Please give more details here:
- how the function work
- what has to be done if the integrity failed
Yes. You are rigth ! This is clearly missing and not understandable
I think this field is useless
Yes and no. Because, like this structure is exported, it may be good to provide this value.
Does it make sence to update infoPtr by infoTempPtr at the end of the function ?

Yes. The update of infoPtr by infoTempPtr is done only on the first call to register the values if we do not call a pa_flash_ScanUbi() before.
At the next calls, we just perform comparisons to check the integrity.
Note that these values are updated when a write is performed on an UBI container using the PA flash.
Error message does not explain what went wrong in this case, please reword.
Comment above could be part of error message, please reword.
Please add a comment here to explain the difference with the error code checking that is done in pa_flash_ScanUbi() below.
As discussed, instead of this, return LE_OK (mean that the function has successfully checked the integrity), and add a parameter to get the integrity result

commits.commitMessage:
Prevent partition access concurrency during fwupdate

In order to prevent modem components to concurrently access partitions
during fwupdate resume process, this patch updates the SSDATA
bad_image bit field according to the state of the partition being
updated.
Corresponding bad_image bit is set during update to indicate ongoing
operation, and cleared at the end of the process.

Resolves: LE-6883
Change-Id: I111236f08e7b47e083c87c4f0d1ac165ec5676bd
commits.subject: Prevent partition access concurrency during fwupdate

comments.message: In my understanding, you should also mark the image good here.

Sonar [MAJOR c:S134]

> Refactor this code to not nest more than 4 if|for|do|while|switch statements.
You need to add the management of bad image in this service also.
According to Gaëtan, this is useless.
In this case, we need to mark all images good.
I think you need to mark all images good at start-up. If the fwupdateDaemon is stopped or if the module reboot while flashing you should prevent about a lock.
According to Gaëtan, this is useless.
Flip the test. Use also a define for 0xFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF.
test each call separably for LE_FAULT and LE_BAD_PARAMETER, it would be clearer
if nothing to be done then I think that the else should be removed
How about using ClearSsdataBadImage instead of repeating the code ?
not needed, res is already = LE_FAULT in that case
Why not creating a single function that can be used in all files ?
not needed. I really think that you should create a function and use it in all files
If the partition does not belong to a system, LE_UNSPPORTED may be used in this case.

I think you were right with LE_BAD_PARAMETER: in the current state of the fwupdate code, if the partition does not belong to a system it is not managed by fwupdate anyway, so the function should reject the parameter.
I don't think that this the wright error code to return
Not the good return code. I prefer LE_NOT_POSSIBLE or better LE_UNSUPPORTED.

No. The better is LE_NOT_POSSIBLE.
LE_UNSUPPORTED is not meaningful in this case.
I think the function should not return here because this is a case where the fwupdate will continue without setting the corresponding bad_image bits anyway.

As in this case, we return LE_NOT_POSSIBLE this does not should mentionned here.
Caller should only test the return code, and apply it in case of LE_OK.
Add comment "Clear SSDATA bad_image on DUAL partition"

Bad alignment.
Also rewrite comment to the be the same as above.
Reword to "CWE image type to set/clear bad_image for"

Prefer if ... else if ... because the test is ==.
Anyway, we can factorize this with:
res = partition_GetBadImageMask( imageType, PARTITION_DUAL_BADMASK == partBadMask, & badImageMask);
Note that tmpMask is useless.
we don't modify the active partition, only the update partition. Do we need to mark it to bad ? no sure...

My understanding was that delta-patches are applied ontop of the content of the active partition into the dual partition: active partition content is read first, then the content is patched into the dual partition.

The idea here is to prevent the active partition from being accessed while fwupdate process needs to read it.
Do we consider the delta patch as failed in this case?

Bad image should not be cleared if patch has failed.
Will remove this.

?
We need to discuss about that case
not sure about that, we need to discuss about that also
Not sure we need to clear the bad image, as we know that the image is bad...
Yes, I think you're right: we shouldn't clear the bad image bits until the whole fwupdate process is OK.
Not sure because is not the job of legato to set the bad image flag in that case.
to factorize. The call is done in the two parts of the if
Previous case was removed, nothing to factorize.

Do not mention SSDATA here, this is internal stuff.

No need underscore in "bad_image"
Set bad image flag on DUAL partition
useless you can passed PARTITION_DUAL_BADMASK directly in the function call, no?
Not sure Legato has to mark an active partition to bad...

partition_SetBadImage()
I would prefer to not mention SSDATA as it is linked to the target (also in the comments)
We could use the enumerate type name
Do we consider the delta patch as failed in this case?

The documentation of the prototype of this function says that it returns "others depending of the UBI or flash functions return".
If the flag was cleared successfully it will return LE_OK, otherwise something is probably wrong with the partition or qmi/modem: fwupdate should not be considered successful in that case I think.

This would be called only the first time we write into the partition (maybe using CurrentImageOffset ?). And I think it would be better to mark the image to bad before programming the flash for the first time.
do we considerer the write image as failed because the bad image clear has failed?

If the clear operation fails it means there is something wrong with the partition or qmi/modem: fwupdate should not be consider successful in this case I think.
Do you suggest to leave the flag on the partition at the end of the write if the clear operation fails here ?
For me if the badimage doesn't work we should only disable the resume. A one time download has no reason to be trouble by this problem.

Not sure about the behavior of the SBL with a good image mark to bad... and do we need to continue an update if the ssdata is not reachable ? not sure... 
So let's go with an error, we will see if an improvement is requested here if we meet that case.

In all case, a LE_ERROR should be log here

why goto on error in that case?
The fact that the bad image write failed impacts the resume feature only.

If set operation fails then there might be something wrong with the partition or qmi/modem: fwupdate should not continue in this case I think.
Otherwise how do you want to handle this case ?

the fact that this operation fails is not related to the partition. It's only a problem with QMI. 
We should only disable the resume feature.

comments.message: Do you think we could simply read in ssdata to know the running ssid ?
No the ssdata can be modified during runtime.
No. This is a protection against a SWAP done or SSDATA modified before the fwupdate starts.
function naming: GetInitialSubSystemIdentifiers , having a function which returns a system number has no sence, we should consider the ssid only
Please return 3 values for modem, lk and linux ssid :)

Three values are returned. Into the initBootSys array.
The function returns LE_OK if it has worked.
Yes, I understood, but this is not readable...
update the comment to define the format
use common defines with qmi ones

commits.commitMessage:
[SW Update] Add new API to force update without synchronizing the systems

New API pa_fwupdate_DisableSyncBeforeUpdate() may be called to force the
update on systems that are not synchronized.
This API is usable only on dual systems.

Resolves: LE-7015
Change-Id: If89264057080bc72b6d58b556a2e5b2961b7eadd
commits.subject: [SW Update] Add new API to force update without synchronizing the systems

commits.commitMessage:
[SW Update] customer0/1 partition broken after sync le_fwupdate_DualSysSync()

Check if destination partiton is mounted before performing the sync. If yes,
the operation is aborted or skipped if the partition is customer0/1.

Resolves: LE-6825
Change-Id: I3144ba3632c4b5d4e393320b9ace7ed46d4e2f27
commits.subject: [SW Update] customer0/1 partition broken after sync le_fwupdate_DualSysSync()

comments.message:
do we abort the rest of the sync or continue with the next partition?
If we abort, perhaps it's better to check all the partitions before?

Yes and no... Because some copy are long and so it may happen that a partition is mounted or attached while copying the previous. So I prefer to check just before.

I think that CUST0, which is dedicated to customer, should be skipped if mounted (customer has to be logical with its own application), but the others (TZ, RPM, MODEM, ABOOT, BOOT, SYSTEM and LEGATO) will exit with an error.

messages. Send a pa_fwupdate_RequestUpdate() before trying to update
the flash and send a pa_fwupdate_CompleteUpdate() when done.

seen as mounted or attached to UBI devices.

comments.message: This function is too long. Maybe it makes sense to create a new file for delta.
variables are not limited in length, so why writing them in minimum of characters ? inLen, inOffset mean nothing, I need to see the usage of them to understand their naming.
better to use false as it is a boolean
better to use false as it is a boolean
it's better to use a defined as it is used several times to avoid mismatch if the path changes later.
test with -1 as it is the error value for open ?
it could be nice to have this comment with the doxygen flags (to identify sections)

In all functions below, please identify which functions are impacted by the call of this function.
Fo instance, in pa_flash_CheckBadBlock(), add a sentence like:
"This function is working on PEB or LEB depending on the call of pa_flash_Scan()/pa_flash_Unscan()"
You explained me this seek, but I forgot the reason we need. Can you add a comment please ?
Shouldn't we do the bad block check only if pa_flash_Scan() was called before ?
pools are created at initialization. Could we have an init function instead of doing this like that ?
Maybe add a comment to explain that bad blocks are skipped
This function is rewritten with LE-6208.

commits.commitMessage:
Resume a firmware update download, and update notification

Implement the read and write operations regarding the storage
of the update status in EFS for RO systems.
Address only the systems supporting the dual system feature.
Relocate the pa_fwupdate_GetUpdateStatusLabel function
from pa_fwupdate.h to pa_fwupdate_dualsys.h.
Redefine the set of internal update status values.
Apply the right internal PA status values.
Record the "on going" status of the download when it starts.

SW update- Support the download resume in fwupdate service
          - Return LE_CLOSED when FD close is detected
          - Replace select by epoll
          - Clean the code
          - Do not allow to swap if a resume context is active

pa_fwupdate_DualSysSwap will return LE_BUSY on this case

SW Update-Update NVUP strategy
- a NVUP file can be downloaded alone,
- when a MODEM is downloaded without NVUP the status of the download is
  OK

Resolves: LE-6419 LE-6420
Related: LE9XXX-586 LE9XXX-515 LE-6220 LE9XXX-705 LE9XXX-767 LE9XXX-769 LE-6381
Change-Id: I647f988438557a33c0298df9e12d6dfb3ad7584b
commits.subject: Resume a firmware update download, and update notification

comments.message: I think CRC (and the context in general) would be always updated, whatever we can open and write the file or not
Here, we're updating only the fields related to the files. If we can't open the files these fields are useless.

oups, sorry, you're right, I thought it was the binary CRC.
That's correct
